author: Celeste Bott St. Louis Post-Dispatch
title: Greitens: St. Louis should not be an 'Abortion Sanctuary City'
text:
Buy Now Laurie Skrivan 
More than 100 people showed to meet Missouri Governor-Elect Eric Greitens during a Thank You Tour stop on Saturday, Jan. 7, 2017, at RBO PrintLogistix in Maryland Heights. Photo by Laurie Skrivan, lskrivan@post-dispatch.com 
JEFFERSON CITY • Gov. Eric Greitens took to Facebook this weekend to slam St. Louis aldermen for a bill adding reproductive health decisions to the city’s anti-discrimination ordinance. 
The bill, which took effect last week, bans employers and landlords from discriminating against women who have had an abortion, use contraceptives or are pregnant. 
"This bill attacks clinics that help women," Greitens wrote. 
The change has been met with opposition from nonprofit "alternative to abortion agencies," sometimes called "pregnancy resource centers," which counsel women against having abortions. Greitens allocated $6 million in funding for such clinics in his 2018 budget proposal. 
"Now St. Louis liberals and the National Abortion Rights Action League are trying to undermine and destroy them," Greitens accused. 
Bills moving through the GOP-led Legislature would effectively block the changes to the ordinance on the grounds that it inhibits the free speech and religious rights of alternative-to-abortion agencies. 
Aldermen have already raised concerns that signing such measures into law would undermine a city's local control. 
Greitens said he would team up with lawmakers but did not mention that legislation specifically, and a spokesman for the governor could not be reached for comment. 
"We're working with legislators, faith leaders, women's advocates, and anyone who values life to fight back against this Abortion Sanctuary City movement," Greitens wrote. Political Fix from the St. Louis Post-Dispatch
